[h1]DOM Traversal[/h1] jQuery has many useful methods for DOM traversal. The [b]parent()[/b] method returns the direct parent element of the selected element. For example: [b]HTML[/b]: [code format="html" ]
div element

[/code] [b]JS[/b]: [code format="js" codeId="1122"]var e = $("p").parent(); e.css("border", "2px solid red");[/code] The code above selects the parent element of the paragraph and sets a red border for it. [note]Run the code to see it in action.[/note]

[h1]DOM Traversal[/h1] The [b]parent[/b]() method can only traverse a single level up the DOM tree. To get all ancestors of the selected element you can use the [b]parents[/b]() method. For example: [b]HTML[/b]: [code format="html" ] body
div

[/code] [b]JS[/b]:[code format="js" codeId="1123"]$(function() { var e = $("p").parents(); e.css("border", "2px solid red"); });[/code] The code above sets a red border for all parents of the paragraph. Some of the most used traversal methods are presented below: [img id="3044" width="100%"]

quizzes.textContent:
[h1]DOM Traversal[/h1]

The [b]eq()[/b] method can be used to select a specific element from multiple selected elements.
For example, if the page contains multiple div elements and we want to select the third one: [code format="js" ]$("div").[b]eq[/b](2);[/code]
[note]The index numbers start at 0, so the first element will have the index number 0.[/note]
